reviewText: On the cover of this movie, it says "Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat." However, this is far from Dr. Seuss' Cat in the Hat. This is Universal Studios' Cat in the Hat, and trust me, these two cats in hats are completely different. Dr. Seuss' book was a fun and humorous book, great for kids of all ages. However, when it came to making the movie, the plot offered by the book must not have made a long enough story, so the movie is filled with crude humor and stupid jokes that try too hard to be funny. The plot is flimsy, and much of the "humor" is not appropriate for kids. Take a pass on this movie and read the real Dr. Seuss' Cat in the Hat instead.

reviewText: Here I am again, trying to explain why I rented a movie made from a book.  Against my better judgement I have seen three such films this year and every time I have been disappointed.  You'd think I would have learned something by now, but hope does spring eternal.  On the other hand, you'd think that Hollywood would have learned that just because you *can* make a movie, doesn't mean that you should.The book Cat in the Hat by Dr. Seuss is a true children's classic about a brother and sister who start one rainy day alone and bored, only to find an unexpected adventure with a tall cat who comes knocking at their door.  This cat is full of magical tricks and surprises, but the children soon learn that there is a price to be paid for all the fun; the house is a wreck and mom is coming home soon.  How can they fix everything in time?The movie Cat in the Hat takes a very liberal interpretation of the delightful children's book.  As a matter of fact, it hardly resembles the book at all.  In order to stretch a small rhyming picture book into an hour and a half movie, the screenwriters had to distort the original story, add several characters and subplotlines and entierely do away with anything that resembled the original.  The preview clips that advertised TCITH in theaters made it seem as if the movie kept true to Dr. Seuss' book, but that's just not true.  Even the rhyming verse is edited and stretched out to fit.  You can't improve upon perfection, only ruin it.  Couldn't they have left that alone, at least?I do have some good things to say about the actors involved.  Mike Myers, who plays the Cat, did the best possible job that could have been done with the role he had to work with here.  I have always admired his comedy and he does have some good moments as the Cat.  The little girl who plays Sally is absolutely precious; both kids are good actors, in my opinion.  There's a lot to be said for the valiant attempts at set design and art direction in this film as well.  It can't be easy to translate Seuss's weird, wild style into a three dimensional world for film, but the result kept the feeling of the book's artwork reasonably well despite that challenge.If you have kids that are just dying to see this movie because they love the book and can't imagine that it would disappoint them, this could be a good object lesson for them.  It is a harmless way to kill an hour and a half.  There was nothing really objectionable in TCITH other than overall mediocrity.  Otherwise I can't find a good reason to recommend this movie to anybody.-Andrea, aka Merribelle
summary: If you love Dr. Seuss' book, don't see the movie.

reviewText: I wasn't much impressed with Jim Carrey's "Grinch," but I had higher hopes for this one. You've got great source material (which is admittedly tough to stretch to an hour and a half), two up-and-coming young actors in Dakota Fanning and Spencer Breslin, and of course, the very, very funny Mike Myers (sporting a great makeup job) as the mischievous Cat. Seemed like it couldn't fail, right? Well...What a dreadful disappointment. Myers tries hard, and the kids are fun, but this film is just one tired cliche after another. It's silly and inane and insulting rather than funny. With very little to work with (the book was what? 2 dozen pages or so?) Myers has to improvise a great deal to fill in the gaps between set pieces. Sometimes he's funny, especially when he's referencing some of his prior work (Dr. Evil, Wayne's World) and parodying pop-culture figures. Problem is, some kids--even pop-culture savvy ones--may not catch some of his broad cultural references (though adults will) and that may leave them a little bored or restless. It's obvious when the material begins to run thin, because we are suddenly treated to potty humor and mild innuendo (nothing really bad, but is it really necessary?) and bombastic physical comedy--though the "rocket car" scenes were funny in an out-of-control, Roadrunner/Coyote kind of way. But far too many of the gags misfire, and the film seems to assume once too often that "manic and frenzied" equals "funny." Nope. The whimsy and humor of the original story is completely subverted here. What a waste of time, money, and talent.Want to entertain your kids with Dr. Seuss? Read the book instead.
summary: What a mockery of Seuss' classic story

reviewText: Like many people, I heard a lot of negative things about "Cat in the Hat," so many in fact that I felt I had to see it to find out if the negative reviews were warranted.  After all it's a classic Dr. Suess story, brought to larger-than-life by Mike Myers, what's not to like?  Well, here's a partial list.Our first introduction to the children the cat entertains involves watching the boy sled down the stairs of his home on a cookie sheet, doing no serious damage to the house or himself.  Remember, this isn't a cartoon kid doing it, but a real, live one.  Do you want your children to try sledding down stairs on a cookie sheet?When the cat shows up he makes two neutering jokes in less than twenty minutes.  Your kids are bound to catch one of them.  Do you want to explain to your children what neutering is?At one point, the cat and the kids are jumping on a couch.  The little girl says its like a circus, to which the cat replies, "Without the drunken clowns with hepatitis."  Do you want to explain to your children what hepatitis is?Later, the cat is doing a parody of a cooking show and cuts the end off his tail.  He screams, "Son of a *****."  The explicative is beeped out, but he is clearly saying something that begins with a "B."  Do you want to explain to your children what he is saying?Interspersed in the cat's routines are snatches of effeminate gay-man stereotypes.  Do stereotypes of any sort have a place in modern children's movies?  Do you want your children imitating gay-man stereotypes?If you've read these quetions I've listed and thought, "That's no big deal."  By all means, go rent "Cat in the Hat" and heaven help you.  Otherwise, forget this travesty and get the original 1971 cartoon with Alan Sherman, a true children's classic with no neutering jokes, deleted explicatives or hurtful stereotypes.
summary: Is this movie right for your kids?

reviewText: Though I have an extensive DVD library and I own several of his movies, I'm not particularly a Mike Myers fan; I think he ought to be hung by the neck for what he did in "The Love Guru". But I must congratulate him over what he achieved in this one: managing to mix his patented bawdy humor with the innocent and chaotic tale of destruction that "The Cat in the Hat" is.And he succeeds wonderfully; Myers only misses a beat twice in the movie. One, is when he overacts as a "couch mechanic" (you ought to see it) and wrestles with an elephant trunk. It's curious, since it's the sort of weird humor I enjoy and write about, but he only managed to make me frown in that scene.Which killed Mr. Myers' comedic pacing a little. Good thing he recovers quickly and more zany fun ensues. His second misstep is with the S.L.O.W. vehicle; it'd usually lend itself to more silly mischief, but I guess that's a prop he didn't know how to milk properly.My favorite scene, though, was the one where he pokes fun at stupid infomercials; he's absolutely at his best there.Overall, and in spite of these tiny flaws, I really enjoyed this movie. I recommend it heartily, but I also advise you to rent this movie first, before plunging your cash into it. You know how that warning goes: "your sense of humor may vary". Mine is utterly twisted and loved it.
summary: The Cat: a wonderful fantasy romp!

reviewText: "The Cat In The Hat" feature film is really just a platform for Mike Myers to dress up and get goofy. The biggest problem I have with this film, is that not only are there naughty jokes for adults, but they are jokes that kids understand. Disney is good about putting jokes in their films that adults will laugh at and kids won't understand. Jokes parents will take offense to are the cat calling a rake "a dirty hoe" and than kissing it, the cat cutting off his tale and than begining to yell the B word which gets bleeped, and the cat singing about being neutered. Small children won't understand the jokes, but when the kid turns 8, you should stop letting them watch it untill they are 13. The storyline is that one day when Sally and Comrade's mom leaves them with a sleeping babysitter, a mysterious talking cat with his magic hat comes to teach them what being a kid is all about. There isn't actually enough story to fill 90 minutes. The film is basically joke after joke after joke.This DVD release is very good. The behind the scenes footage isn't as indepth as I would like it to be, but it is enough to let you know how they made the movie. I am surprised to find that Universal didn't go the Disney route with this DVD and add a ton of games. There is only one special feature that kids will want to do, and that is the learn to dance like the cat feature. The deleted scenes are nice, and some of them include early special effects. A decent DVD.The best part about this movie is Thing 1 and Thing 2. They are wacky and hilarious. This movie isn't sutible for every member of the family, and parents with kids who repeat everything they hear should not let their kids watch "The Cat In The Hat."

reviewText: Nothing really like the book, but I decided by the end of the film that it doesn't make this movie bad. Even though his performance of the Cat in the Hat at times reminded me of the Cowardly Lion or Snagglepuss with an Austin Powers laugh, Mike Myers does make the cat come to life. The children in the movie do a great job as well.The scenery of the film stayed true to the world of Dr. Seuss and looked great, even though much of it was once again not in the book. It looked like I was watching a Seuss book come to life.I was surprised with how many adult jokes made it into the film, not that it bothered me, but I wouldn't expect some of the things hinted at would be hinted at in a movie based on a children's classic. It's kind of like watching Shrek, adults will get some jokes that kids might not get.Overall a good movie, but if you are expecting this to be exactly like the book, you are going to be very disappointed because this is almost nothing like the book. But like I said, that doesn't necessarily mean that makes it a bad film. I didn't think so, but it's just one of those things that you have to make your own judgments about once you watch it.

reviewText: The Cat in the Hat is one of the most beloved children's books ever. It's surely Dr. Seuss' most famous. So the prospect of bringing it to the world of film for kids to be re-introduced to its magic (which worked for The Grinch) seemed like a great idea.It WAS a good idea.This movie, however, is about as fun as a hairball. It takes the basic story of little kids Sally and Conrad, their fish, and the mischievous talking cat who makes their rainy day more interesting and stomps on it with adult jokes, lame impersonations, unpleasant supporting characters, and just plain stupidity. Mike Myers is a very funny guy, but here he's like a retarded Cowardly Lion on speed, turning into cooking show hosts, plumbers, pinatas, salsa dancers, and so on, each and every one of them 100% not funny. Throw in double entendres that could be almost acceptable if they were actually FUNNY (The Cat steps on a hoe and says, 'Dirty ho.' Not funny. Oh, but then he brings it BACK and starts to put his TONGUE ON IT. HA HA HA! LAUGH!)I'm going into a rant now. I guess the movie is fun for kids that just like noise and silly voices or stoners or people who hate the book, or even people willing to see the movie as a Mike Myers vehicle like Austin Powers. I, however, found it to be one of the worst adaptations of anything, and I just pray there won't be a sequel (there's a second book, though. Yikes.)Oh, and Alec Baldwin, who plays the sleazy neighbor? He skipped the Oscars, where he was nominated, to record commentary for this movie. I thought he was the SMART Baldwin.
summary: Ha ha ha! Wait, it's not funny

reviewText: Yeash. I couldn't even watch the second half of this film. I think that it was one of the WORST movies ever made! And the kids in the story were like REAL kids, not Holloywoodish pretty-faced children.Mike Myers is a brilliant character actor; there can be no argument there. (Frankly, I don't find him to be at all funny however.) But, his take on the Cat in the Hat character is, well, disturbing. It's like watching a VERY adult comedy making fun of kids' films. And ADULT is how I would describe it, as there is an awful lot of (strange, and disturbing) sexual humor here. It seems to me like this film is a complete bastardization of Seuss. Despite what critics think, I'd recommend watching Jim Carrey's brilliant performance in "the Grinch" before watching this flop. (Not that it was such a good film either.)The DVD design here is kinda cheap. They tried to add some nice features, but it all seemed trashy to me. And there's an awful lot of junk you gotta get through to even get to the film itself. Yuck.

reviewText: I simply don't understand all the poor reviews on this film. I think it proves that many of the people who went to see this film had no idea of what to expect from Dreamworks and Mike Myers. If you like the Austin Powers movies you will really like this. No it wasn't some dumb children's Disney movie. It was edgy and had a more of a sophisticated interpretation of the original Dr. Seuss book.I'm guessing the problem is that most of those were expecting a re-enactment of the original children's book. And I doubt seriously Mike Myers or Dreamworks would do such a movie as that. My philosophy on movie and books is simply they are not one and of the same. The children's classic The Cat In the Hat was meant to be one of the first books a child could learn to read. It featured a wonderful use of colorful words to go along with the wonderful illustrations of that era of printed children's publishing. If that is what one expects then they would be best just stick to the classic original children's book. I would wager a bet that most of the parents who complained about this movie never bothered to give their children the book. Instead they just take their brats to the multiplex and expect them to have the same experience as actually reading the children's book.No this is a highly entertaining and humorous critic of modern American life. The character of Mr. Humberfloob (Sean Hayes) and Quinn (Alec Baldwin) along with the mom played by Kelly Preston and the two wonderful child actors do in fact present a satire of modern life. No, children like Sally did not have Palm Pilot organizers in the original book. And no the children in the original book were not as uptight and materialistic as those of 2003. So naturally the Cat (Mike Myers) had to be more sophisticated and edgy.Bottom line this movie is a view of modern day life in uptight urban America. It simply follows the storyline from Dr. Seuss's children's book. It was not meant to be a remake of the printed book. And if there are those out there that thought so then God help them. And unfortunately it seems this movie is a waste for them because them are simply too dumb to get it.

reviewText: "The Cat in the Hat," (2003) a delightful children's book by Dr. Seuss, has been turned into a sleazy, nasty, distasteful film starring Mike Myers. It's full of unpleasant adult humor. It's hard for me to think of a more disagreeable piece of filmmaking than this travesty. Everyone in the film is unlikable and nasty. Alec Baldwin is particularly noxious. They took a cute kid's story and turned it into really awful stuff: gross, coarse "potty humor" of the worst kind. It's in bad taste, and I would certainly warn parents to be aware of what they and their kids are stepping in.A brother and sister are left in the house under the care of a babysitter who can't stay awake while their mother goes out to do her real estate stuff. The smarmy neighbor, Baldwin, shows up as does the Cat in the Hat. The Cat turns out to be an obnoxious, snide pest who ruins the house.Mike Myers couldn't be any worse even if he tried. Dr. Seuss's story is perverted into a stew of unpleasantness. There's no charm, warmth or fun in this mess. You get the picture: I didn't like this bomb.

reviewText: The idea that Mike Meyers was going to play the title character in "The Cat in the Hat" certainly sounded like a good idea and the makeup job is pretty good, but as soon as he shows up in this 2003 film and starts channeling either Bert Lahr or Linda Richman (I am not sure which) for some reason you get a bad feeling.  When you add an inane subplot involving Alec Baldwin as a neighbor with plans for the mom (Kelly Preston) of precocious kids Conrad (Spencer Breslin) and Sally (Dakota Fanning), that bad feeling only grows and then comes the point where you realize that this film is just not funny and that is game, set, match for one of the most disappointing children's films ever made.There are some good points to the film.  Redoing the Dreamworks bit at the start of the movie in the illustration style of Dr. Seuss was a nice touch and the production design by Alex McDowell(currently working on "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory") is in keeping with the spirit of the beloved author and his cherished book.  But then people start showing up and talking, at which point your mind is consumed with visions of frantic grave spinning.  Adults love the book too and our fond memories of reading it for the first gazillion couple of times is what draws us here, not the promise of adult humor directed narrowly above the heads of the small fry.I am not really all that concerned with how much of the blame has to do with Meyers and his presence, both in terms of ad libs and writing to his peculiar style of humor, and how much is because screenwriters Alec Berg, David Mandel, and Jeff Schaffer were trying to expand the story to fill up a great big movie like this one.  The added sibling rivalry element is fine (he is compulsively messing up and she is a control freak), but letting Baldwin run around and be annoying was a big mistake while the bits with mom's job and the baby sitter were both unnecessary.  The original story of "The Cat in the Hat" was about what happened between two kids and the Cat in the Hat while their mother was not about.  There was an irate fish and the troublemaking twins Thing 1 and Thing 2, but that was it and if the people making this movie could not make it work with those characters then tossing in this other nonsense was not going to help.The humor represented by what Baldwin's Quinn does and what happens to the babysitter Mrs. Kwan (Amy Hill) are both way beyond the pale.  Dr. Seuss did not do potty jokes nor was he malicious.  Theodore Geisel was creative and imaginative, while those responsible for this travesty are woefully bereft of those qualities.  Dr. Seuss wrote stories to inspire children to read and here the goal is to make money (certainly they made a lot less than they thought they would: the film cost $109 million and grossed only $100 million domestically).  I would want to draw some lesson for future reference having to do with never trying to turn Dr. Seuss into anything more than a half-hour television program and not a bloated 82-minute constrosity, but we all know that Hollywood is slow to learn anything.  Apparently there are some people not even Dr. Seuss can teach.
summary: They didn't listen to the tagline: "Don't mess with the hat"

reviewText: If you thought that film production companies such as Dream Works, Universal Pictures and Imagine Entertainment would be able to transform a $109-million budget, an all-star cast and a very famous Dr. Seuss (a.k.a. Theodor S. Geisel, 1904-1991) children's book into a hit film in 2003, you were mistaken.  Instead, the film production of "The Cat in the Hat", starring Mike Myers and Alec Baldwin and directed by Bo Welch, was a box-office disaster of epic proportions: earning a paltry $38-million in gross U.S. box-office receipts.  In spite of the lavish sets, costumes and special effects done in a myriad of bright, pastel colors and superb makeup that visually transformed Mike Myers into Seuss's infamous cat, the dialog, acting and side plot utterly failed to inspire, engage, entertain or capture the imaginations of the audience.  Except for a scant number of infrequent jokes that inspired brief responses of laughter, the majority of the film's 82 minutes are dry, humorless and dull.The film begins in a Seuss-inspired township of imaginative colors and architecture in the real estate firm owned by Mr. Humberfloob (Sean Hayes, better known for his portrayal of Jack in the ongoing TV sitcom of "Will & Grace"), who suffers from an obsessive-compulsive disorder.  Though intended to be funny, Mr. Humberfloob's yelling is merely annoying.  Working for him is the mother (Kelly Preston) of the two children that will soon be visited by Mike Myer's vision of Seuss's cat.  While being babysat by the overly drowsy Mrs. Kwan (Amy Hill), the children, the disobedient Conrad (Spencer Breslin) and the peremptory Sally (Dakota Fanning), are visited mysteriously by Mike Myers as the Cat in the Hat.  Not having been engaged by any of the characters thus far, Mike Myers arrival is disappointing as he proceeds to vapidly attempt to humor the children out of their boredom and bad behavior.  The most interesting characters, Thing One (Danielle Chuchran & Taylor Rice) and Thing Two (Brittany Oaks & Talia-Lynn Prairie), are by far the most entertaining characters in the film.  Alec Baldwin as the mother's would-be suitor/neighbor named Quinn (a product of poetic license), is often offensive and utterly humorless.Though the cinematography and special effects are quite good, these alone could not save this film's inability to be in any way entertaining.  It is conceivable that Jim Carrey (who did an excellent job of playing Seuss's grinch in the 2000 "How the Grinch Stole Christmas") would have been better able to portray the Cat in the Hat as compared to Mike Myers, but that is something that will probably never be known.  Sadly, the best that I can rate the 2003 film version of "The Cat in the Hat" is 2 out of 5 stars.  My only advice to anyone wanting to know the actual story is to read Dr. Seuss's original 1957 book with its original illustrations.
summary: Visually Stunning, But Horrible Dialog, Acting & Direction

reviewText: I'm usually not the type of person who lashes out at film versions of books, plays, what have you, when they are altered from their original text (I cringe when I read such phrases as "Broadway musicals mucked up by Hollywood"), as if the originals were sacred. They are adaptations of those works, and thus entities into themselves. But with this unnecessarily complicated film of the simple, endearing Dr. Seuss classic, there's nothing to do here but complain. Why they would adapt a children's book that takes less than 10 minutes to read to a child into an 82-minute feature is beyond me.There is literally nothing at all good about this movie. Not a single thing whatsoever. Mike Myers plays the cat as if he were someone's oafish, annoying uncle from Queens doing a botched magic act. He often reverts to variations on his old SNL schticks to keep things from going downhill and fails miserably.The script, if it could be called such, clogs up the film's simple message of mixing fun with caution with an unnecessary subplot. Alec Baldwin's character of a loutish, hateful suitor to the children's mother wants to send the boy (the decidedly un-cute Spencer Breslin) to military school. After seeing the way the kids act in this film, he may be right, but the subplot could have been cut.Many of the other new characters are just window dressing. Talented character actress Amy Hill is wasted as a fat, narcoleptic Taiwanese babysitter does absolutely nothing at all. Sean Hayes (who ruins everything he's in) is there as the mother's boss only to suggest that Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder is innately funny. As the voice of the goldfish, Hayes provides no charm or humor, just yelling and screaming.For an alleged family film, this production is unbelievably vulgar and obscene. There is a sequence in a rave, of all places, and who else makes a cameo but amateur filmmaker (to use a polite phrase) Paris Hilton.First-time director Bo Welch has no sense of comic timing or pacing whatsoever, and for a film that plays as if it were on fast forward, it seems awfully long. Considering his production design background, one would think he'd use colors other than purple, green, and orange for the hideous, expensive sets.Do not, under any circumstances, view this vile, crass, obscene, offensive, annoying film in any way shape or form. For a better audiovisual adaptation of Dr. Seuss' feline, pick up the charming 1971 TV cartoon on DVD instead.

reviewText: Perhaps with "Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat," we can finally declare an official moratorium on any future live-action film adaptations of that beloved author's classic work.  This is an even more egregious fiasco than the earlier "How the Grinch Stole Christmas," the film that stands, shockingly and inexplicably, as the box office champion of 2000.  (Oh well, at least "The Cat in the Hat" didn't emerge as the highest-grossing film of 2003. We should at least be grateful for small favors, I guess).Mike Myers embarrasses himself to no end playing the crazed feline who bursts into the lives of two bored youngsters one dull rainy afternoon.  Myers' interpretation of the cat seems to derive its inspiration from the Charles Nelson Reilly school of lowbrow comedy. Though the film borrows the basic premise from the book, the screenplay and direction do everything possible to violate the spirit of the source, replacing the original's cleverness, subtlety and literary wit with manic pacing, unctuous caricatures, and foul, inappropriately sexual and scatological humor.  The film's production design is indeed a wonder to behold, capturing the parti-colored splendor of the original book's illustrations to a tee.  This is not, however, the case with the bizarre and repulsive suit the costume designers have fashioned for Meyers to inhabit.  Indeed, the only thing saving Myers from total embarrassment here is the fact that the mask he's been forced to don at least hides his identity to some meager extent (poor Alec Baldwin, as a particularly obnoxious secondary character, is given no such protective covering to hide HIS understandably reddened face behind).Unlike the classic tale on which it is based, "The Cat in the Hat" is a soulless, joyless enterprise that will depress generations of children to come as well as the bewildered adults who will be joining them in the experience.  Really, who of any age wants to look at a cat's naked posterior or Baldwin's prosthetic beer belly, both of which are given ample and merciless display here?  What a sad state Hollywood has come to when this is what movie moguls think passes for fine cinematic fun for the whole family.
Title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat In The Hat

reviewText: Oh, where to start.  No surprises here - this is a flick that will do anything for a kid's laugh, even if that means it will send Seussians into a frenzy, or have Seuss himself doing 360's in his grave.  Let's get the bad out of the way - this flick is simplistic, goes for the easy laugh, relies heavily on expensive production and special effects and makes no attempt to build on the magic of the story and milks it dry.  Worse, it doesn't even use the extended length of what was originally a story you could read in a few minutes to develop its own magic.That said (and now that we know we're not going to see Seuss get his due), "Cat" is still fun.  If unsurprising, it manages to satisfy.  Everybody knows the story - Conrad and Sally, brother and sister, are waiting out a rainy day at home when (for no reason, and without any explanation) the cat appears and begins to tear up the house for laughs.  Soon the cat enlists the aid of Thing #1 and Thing #2.  The movie stretches things out - Conrad (who was the nameless narrator of the story - the cat can never get his name right here in one of the movie's running jokes) is a rascal who never does what he's supposed to; Sally is a control freak and compulsively complies with rules (she envies Conrad who has more rules than she does).  Their mother (played by the lovely Kelly Preston) will be hosting a party at home for her boss - a real estate super-agent with a Seussian name and a nasty obsession for sanitary hands.  Meanwhile, a sinister neighbor (Alec Baldwin) with an eye on Mom, conspires to get Conrad into a military school in order to remove an obstacle between himself and mom.  Obviously, the cat will teach the kids to find the happy medium of spontaneous fun of less-than-mass-destruction, while thwarting the evil Baldwin character.  Meyers plays the cat as a mix of his "Coffee Talk" lady and a more jovial version of Burt Lahr's "Cowardly Lion".  Meyers is irrepressible as the Cat, and if he misses the story's, he captures the movie's conceit, which is well aware of how short it falls from the original (Myers's cat kicks things off once Conrad and Sally sign a bunch of legal waivers; the cat also never goes anywhere without his magical, time-traveling elves, a trio of uptight suits who only look like lawyers; Myers also proves rather limited in the rhyme department).Dedicated Seussians aside, it could have been a lot worse - preachy, treacly or simply infantile like some extended Nickelodeon cartoon - "Cat" has decent laughs and won't put you to sleep like more acceptable kiddie fair.  Warning though, this flick more closely straddles the line of good taste than other kid-flicks - with several near utterances of not-ready-for Niktoons dialog and plenty of double-entendres which will have you thinking "isn't this supposed to be a kids' movie?" (not to mention Myers as plumber, complete with sagging hip-hugger jeans), but I doubt most kids will pick up on them.  I took my 4 and 6 year olders to see it and we all had a ball.  On the other hand, I've finally found a kids flick I can enjoy as much as my kids do (even if the enjoyment ain't that great).  In short, if you are a true devotee of Suess, you'll probably want to stick clear of this flick (catch "Return of the King" instead, if accuracy and loyalty are your creeds).  Otherwise, this flick is still fun.
summary: Fun (unless you're a diehard Seussian - then one star)

It was obviously intended to be a film aimed at kids, but ends up being more bizarre and disturbing than intended(or was it intended?) much like The Garbage Pail Kids movie or Return To Oz.  The movie is a total overdose of utter zaniness and the bizarre.  In fact, the onlsaught may be too overwhelming for some adults.  Mark my words, this has "cult film" written all over it.  Years from now(if not already), this film will achieve a cult following for those into whacked out movies.  I promise.  To all the conservative parents whining about how "crude" and "Inappropriate" some of the jokes are-Lighten up a bit.  These suggestive themes are shot out so fast that only adults are gonna pick up on them.  Really, they'll fly over your kids' heads, coz they'll be preoccupied with the physical comedy and the overall look of the film.  After viewing, my daughter had no desire to go to a rave, hit on Paris Hilton, call a hoe a "ho", use profanity or whack a guy in the groin with a baseball bat.  Your kids are safe, lighten up a bit.  And if you're kids are old enough to get these jokes, then I'd hope they'd be mature enough to handle them and laugh at them.  I mean, it's not Andrew Dice Clay or anything.  To Dr. Suess fans, I agree with the other reviewers and suggest you stay away.  I hate it when Hollywood butchers a book I like(Hannibal comes to mind), and this is no exception.  But if you like just flat out bizarre stuff, check this out.  Regardless of complaints, this movie is actually very funny, very witty.  Especially a scene where the Cat spoofs that lame informercial show, Amazing Discoveries, that used to be on every morning at 5 a.m.(almost always the same episode with that crazy English guy trying to sell that magic car rejuvination wax or Jack Lelane and his Juice Tiger).  The Cat in the Hat is definitely the newest Hollywood misfire, but that's why it's so fun.  It earns a spot in your dvd collection between Howard The Duck and Caligula.

reviewText: In Japan, where Dakota Fanning is very popular (perhaps more popular than Mike Myers), 'Dr. Seuss's The Cat in the Hat' went straight to video when the year 2004 was almost over.  What is the reason for this reluctant distribution?  Why so ... late?Now, I see it.  The film is not only unfunny; it's criminally unfunny and some might call it offensive because of its awfully misguided gags.  Even kids hate it because its hopeless silliness, and their parents find it appalling because of offen suggested sexual nuances.Mike Myers in prosthetics plays the Cat in the Hat, who visits the house of Little Girl Sally (Fanning) and Little Boy Conrad (Spencer Breslin, 'The Kid').  Sally is a girl who prefers thing in order while Conrad likes mischief-making.  Today is a rainy day, so now The Cat can teach them how to 'have fun.'But how?  Within the short running time (barely exceeds 80 minutes), unrecognizable Mike Myers in cat's makeup plays every tricks on the house's spic-and-span interior decorations, which all turn messy.  And he thinks it's funny.  Funny, too for us, that he doesn't seem to think that this is exactly what is happening to his career.The same goes to the adult actors -- Kelly Preston (who should deserve better roles) plays the kids' Mom as she was many times before.  She wants the house to be clean because her boss doesn't like any potentially dirty things (so, he even abhors handshaking ... ho-hum).  And Alec Baldwin is a 'handsome' neighbor who wants to marry her (she is a single mother).  And of course, he wants to get rid of the kids simply because the film needs an obligatory villain.The only merit of the film is its production designs, which  perfectly fit in this fantasy.  The cinematography of Emmanuel Lubezki ('And Your Mother Too' 'A Walk in the Cloud') gives the impeccable dream-like pastel-color touch to this fictional town where a cat can talk and a goldfish can speak.  If only they thought of a more decent story, or at least some funnier gags.It is a wonder that among this costly confusion of tasteless, meaningless moments, the child actors can retain theit charms to some extent.  But the fact remains that it is a mess, a big, expensive mess which still collected more than $100 m in USA.  Well, what can I say?
summary: The Most Costly Mess in Recent Hollywood History

reviewText: To begin with, there are a lot of people out there who have taken this movie way too seriously. THE CAT IN THE HAT is based/inspired by the beloved children's story by Dr. Seuss. The original book has 72 pages that are mostly illustrations. That's not much source material for a movie, even if it is supposed to be a children's movie. So, the filmmakers expanded the Cat's universe, making it more lively, but in a very unrealistic and cartoony fashion. The movie isn't going to make total sense; it's not supposed to. It's based off a Dr. Seuss book, for Pete's sake.The story revolves around a sister and brother, Sally and Conrad, who are driving their poor single Mom insane with their unruly behavior. Their mother warns them that they better not get in trouble and to keep the house clean as she leaves the house. She loves her children, but is it too much to ask that they not fight and keep the house clean for once? But, while Mom is away, the Cat will play. Sally, Conrad, and Cat find out that this guy named Quinn who kind of likes their Mom is actually not what he appears to be. So the trio sets forth on a mission to keep Quinn from proposing to Mom.Mike Myers is a comical genius and perfectly captures the sprite-like nature of Cat. Dakota Fanning and Spencer Breslin are also well cast as Sally and Conrad. Other than that, there really aren't any other notable acting performances except Paris Hilton's brief cameo.As for as movies go, THE CAT IN THE HAT is a disappointment. The characters could have been so much more interesting and the story more developed. Instead, the movie feels like watching a bunch of beautifully painted pictures pasted together to try to tell a story. Of course, that didn't bother me as much as all the innuendo that is in the movie. This is supposed to be a children's movie, but instead comes off being more like a PG-13 teen comedy. I can forgive the underdeveloped story and characters, but not the implied sexual references. It's just not right. That's probably why the film is so well liked by people over 13.

The way the term was used was to refer to a particular section in the documents that happened to be the 8th section of the contract. Its silly and easy to miss and if you're a child it most likely will go completely over your head. I picked it up after watching it today. I had the movie since it was released on DVD and just popped it in after 6 or 7 years and I just realized how slick that was lol. Its 'stupid/silly' stuff like this.I wouldn't call it innocent at all, its not a dingy movie. Only a person with life experience would pick up on the humor. He was singing in drag and something he was singing about rhymed with 'balls' (as in his ballsack) the music slowed and paused before he could say it- he sits for 4 or 5 secs and thinks of another word (he uses 'boys' instead) and continues singing.Another event was when he was on the homeshopping network or a cooking show similar to a Rachael Rae or Paula Deen. reviewText: It's about a catAnd his big striped hatHe meets a bratThe sister ratsAs pesky as a gnatThey want him to scatBut the house goes splatAnd that was thatSo much for the catAnd his silly hatFor anyone who loves Dr. Seuss this silly movie brings the book to life in full blown color and lots of action. Kelly Preston is the ideal cartoon mom with not a hair out of place despite all the chaos she encounters. Sean Hayes (as Mr. Humberfloob) and Amy Hill (as Mrs. Kwan) offer additional hilarities in their small supporting roles. Overall this movie is a great bit of entertainment for young and old alike and something that can be watched over and over again with a little something new from that silly Cat in the Hat and all his goofy acts.

reviewText: Back in 1953, Dr. Seuss (a pseudonym for Theodore Geisel, author of several successful children's books) wrote the screenplay for THE 5,000 FINGERS OF DR. T, a wildly inventive live-action family film. Unfortunately, it was such a box-office flop that the good doctor tended to avoid the subject in subsequent interviews, and turned his back on live-action movie adaptations of his stories for the remainder of his career. Today THE 5,000 FINGERS OF DR. T is a highly-regarded cult classic, even moreso in the wake of the disastrous DR. SEUSS' HOW THE GRINCH STOLE CHRISTMAS (2000) and this dismal assault on Geisel's legacy, DR. SEUSS' THE CAT IN THE HAT, which has about as much relation to the original Seuss story as it does to any Victor Hugo novel.The still-delightful Seuss tales are full of imagination and whimsical linguistics, attributes that the filmmakers apparently had no faith in, as they sacrificed tone and charm for a succession of loud jokes, smart-alecky quips, and violent sight gags. Sadly, this isn't likely to be Hollywood's last rape of Seuss' body of work, and I wouldn't be surprised to see either Adam Sandler in a big screen adaptation of DR. SEUSS' HOP ON POP or the Wayans Brothers in DR. SEUSS' GREEN EGGS AND HAM in the very near future.
